Award.AwardTitle: Public Engagement in Astronomy and the Outdoors
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides renewed support for an astronomy education partnership between Carthage College and the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC), with the support of Dartmouth College and Rock Point School. The partners will deliver hands-on astronomy and nature education and outreach programs that engage the public, train mentors and docents, and provide experiential learning opportunities for high school and college students. Under the first two years of prior NSF NSF support, Carthage College and the AMC provided astronomy and nature education programming to nearly 3,000 participants in year 1, and 5,000 in year 2. The AMC hosts over 500,000 visitors annually, over half of whom are lower-to-middle-class in income, and approximately 20% are non-white. With renewed NSF funding, the partnership will expand training opportunities, and deliver their programming to an even wider audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program achieved its goals of (1) engaging the public with holistic nature education through astronomy; (2) training Appalachian Mountain Club nature and outdoors educators and volunteers in astronomy; and (3) engaging and training undergraduate physics and astronomy students as science communicators. This effort followed a previous three-year NSF-funded program, and repreented a substanial scale-up in reach and organizational dynamics to engage a larger audience and greater reinforcement of training and preparation. While reach in earlier years ranged from 3000-5000 members of the public, the current effort - which involved six undergraduate interns and one faculty member - reached nearly 12,000 people (with roughly 1/3 children and 2/3 adults), with greater depth and effect. Daily and nightly observing programs, formal public lectures, short 'table talk' presentations, informational posters, table-top cards, handouts, and web resources were all utilized to engage audiences. The content delivered is atypical of astronomy programs in general: Rather than emphasize traditional topics, such as recent research findings, cosmology, black holes, etc., this program emphasized the single story of natural history, human evolution, and the environment as part of a cosmological/Universe vision. Showing how the chemical and biological processes of life on Earth derive from and are linked to the astronomical history and environment better engages audiences, and motivates them to make attitudinal shifts about their place in the natural world and their impact on it. A series of assessment and evaluation tools was utilized to measure program effectiveness and impact. Results of these assessment activities show thatdesired attitudinal shifts were achieved - that individuals were more aware of the equivalence in value of human life to other life on Earth, and that there is a single system which continues to evolve and change - and eventually end. In addition, considerable effort was spent on issues associated with light pollution, a topic which resonated with these audiences (who were generally visiting the White Mountains for a nature experience). The health and environmental effects of light pollution motivated many participants to further inquiry about the issue, and intent to follow up with their respective municipalities and industries.

As a whole - this has been a very effective program. Having conducted these programs for four years, astronomy as a core to nature education is becoming a greater theme in AMC nature programming, and is beginning to be effecrive in changing attitudes and actions of program participants. Participation has motivated a number of AMC seasonal staff and astronomy interns to take on science education as their primary careers, pursuing graduate study or taking teaching positions. Further expanding the program to reach audiences in a wider geographic area, engaging a greater number of undergraduate science students, and formalizing the approaches for export to other institutions and organizations are near-future steps to be taken.
